Legal_Issue: Whether an adjudicator has jurisdiction to order a detention review hearing outside the detention facility
Governing_Law: Subsection 103(9) of the Immigration Act, Rule 7 and Rule 30 of the Immigration and Refugee Board Rules
Decision_Outcome: Adjudicator's decision set aside; hearing must be held within the detention facility
Burden_of_Proof: On the Minister to demonstrate jurisdictional error
Legal_Rule: Hearings should occur in detention facilities unless confidentiality or public safety concerns arise; Rule 7 allows location changes but is constrained by Rule 30
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Grounds_for_Claim: Adjudicator exceeded jurisdiction by relocating the hearing without statutory authority
Outcome_on_Merits: Judicial review allowed; adjudicator's decision invalidated
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of detention center facilities, public access, witness participation issues
Defendant_Response: Adjudicator cited practical concerns such as public access and witness participation
Remedy_Requested: Setting aside of adjudicator's decision and return of hearing to detention facility
Outcome: Court granted remedy; hearing to remain in detention facility
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, arrested twice, failed to report for removal, application for landing delayed and unverified
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to report for removal, delay in application processing

Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and temporary relief from removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Irreparable harm and balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No serious jeopardy to life or safety shown; balance of convenience favors enforcement of immigration laws

Application_Facts: Mr. Acharige argued that the PRRA Officer erred in assessing his risk claims; he claimed risks in Sri Lanka due to political involvement and alleged murder ties.
Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of removal after judicial review application
Evidence_Used: PRRA assessment, RPD findings, applicant's submissions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Arguments found speculative and unsupported by credible evidence
Credibility_Assessment: The RPD and PRRA Officer both concluded Mr. Acharige was not at risk in Sri Lanka; lack of credibility in risk claims
Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal pending resolution of risk claims
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-part test: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on issue
Decision_Rationale: Court found arguments speculative and lacking credible evidence; prior decisions found no risk in Sri Lanka
Authority_Responsible: Federal Court (judicial review), PRRA Officer (administrative decision)

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of submissions and inadequate reasoning
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Absence of documented rationale for decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Procedural unfairness and risk to public safety

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over amended release conditions for Mr. Sittampalam, deemed a danger to the public
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA sections on procedural fairness and decision reasons
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Altering conditions without submissions or reasons
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Parties not given opportunity to respond
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review with motion for stay
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Narcotics trafficking and organized crime links
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Public safety and CBSA monitoring concerns
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Procedural unfairness and potential harm to public safety

Crime_Name: Risk of Persecution or Harm upon Removal
Violation_Type: Failure to assess personalized risk as required by law
Application_Facts: Applicant is a Tamil individual facing potential removal to Sri Lanka; Minister's Delegate concluded risk was generalized, not personalized
Procedural_Issue: Re-assessment process may have failed to properly apply the balance of probabilities test; risk of irreparable harm if removed prior to judicial review
Evidence_Used: Evidence indicating Tamils face unique dangers in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Minister's Delegate dismissed specific risks to Tamils as generalized without sufficient justification
Decision_Outcome: Minister's Delegate found no more than generalized risk
Outcome: Stay of removal granted by the court
Relief_Sought: Stay of removal pending judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of removal until resolution of judicial review
Decision_Rationale: Serious questions exist about the re-assessment; removal would render judicial review ineffective, constituting irreparable harm

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's criminal history and alleged gang leadership raising public safety concerns in Canada versus risk of torture/persecution in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly reassess risks as per prior court order
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on outdated evidence; ignored credible NGO and SLMM reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent weighing of evidence and sources
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Prevention of deportation due to risk of torture
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of risk and balancing exercise
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Flawed evidence treatment and improper balancing of danger to public vs. risk upon return

Crimes.Violation_Type: Deportation based on serious criminality despite refugee status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant’s history of serious criminality and gang involvement while being a Convention refugee
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation due to seriousness of criminal acts
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review following prior court-ordered reassessment
Evidence_Used: Corroborative evidence of targeting by authorities or LTTE
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ignored relevant NGO reports and failed to address corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evaluation of risk evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remanded for new assessment
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Halt deportation due to risk of cruel treatment
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: New risk assessment and balancing under s. 97 and s. 115(2)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to reasonably assess risk of torture and balance against public danger

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to consider updated and credible evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Relevant reports were available but dismissed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable assessment of risk and evidence
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged gang leadership and organized criminal involvement
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: History of serious criminality and gang association
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Danger to the public and organized criminality
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Risk of targeting by Sri Lankan authorities or LTTE upon return
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reassessment
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Flawed evaluation of evidence regarding risk in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Dismissal of corroborative and credible evidence without justification

Crimes.Violation_Type: Use of false documents to enter Canada
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants entered Canada with false documents and made refugee claims that were subsequently rejected
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to entry with false documents
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Yes, use of false documents constitutes misrepresentation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of removal pending judicial review of PRRA decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA assessment, country condition reports, applicants' submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Vague and speculative risk claims, lack of specific evidence on irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims found to be speculative and lacking credibility
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal pending judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-part test: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence of credible risk or irreparable harm; PRRA decision was thorough

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making False Statements under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of PRRA based on alleged risks upon return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicants demonstrated irreparable harm or serious issue to be tried for a stay of removal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims of forced recruitment by LTTE deemed vague and speculative
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, country condition reports, PRRA decision record
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections related to misrepresentation and risk assessment in IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of forced recruitment due to age and family connections
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of individualized risk evidence despite general country conditions
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review with motion for stay of removal
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide specific, credible evidence of personal risk
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; court found submitted evidence insufficient rather than ignored
Crimes.Application_Factor: New evidence considered but found not compelling or relevant
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged false statements in immigration applications

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of refugee and PRRA claims based on misrepresentation and lack of credible risk
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for stay of removal pending judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims assessed as speculative and unsupported by evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of harm due to age and perceived association in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of specific evidence linking applicants to targeted groups
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Motion for stay of removal during judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Inadequate demonstration of irreparable harm or serious issue
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence ignored; rather, evidence presented was deemed insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Application_Factor: Emotional harm to family not recognized as irreparable harm
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False documentation and statements in original application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide parties with opportunity to present submissions on release terms
Outcome: Matter referred back for redetermination by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness, right to be heard
Decision_Rationale: Member made significant changes to conditions not requested or argued by either party

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of organized criminality
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Member failed to allow parties to present submissions on release terms
Outcome: Matter referred back for redetermination by a different officer
Basis_for_Decision: Alteration of release conditions without input
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Changes made without party input or request

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with the recognizance
Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in amending release conditions
Legal_Rule: Parties must have opportunity to be heard

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in modifying release conditions
Legal_Rule: Right to be heard before changes to release conditions
Grounds_for_Claim: Unilateral changes by Member without submissions
Outcome: Decision overturned and matter referred back

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to allow submissions on amended release conditions
Basis_for_Decision: Unauthorized changes to conditions beyond scope of request
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Altered conditions without notice or argument from parties

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with a Recognizance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of continued detention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of immigration detention decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Past gang involvement, credibility issues, unproven allegations
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Crown/Board to justify continued detention
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Board's decision can be overturned if findings unsupported or legal analysis incorrect
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Intermediate standard for mixed fact and law questions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable assessment of danger and alternatives to detention
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Past gang ties, lack of credible bondspersons, rehabilitation efforts
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged detention as unjustified and disproportionate
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of continued detention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of immigration detention decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Past gang involvement, credibility concerns, unproven allegations
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Board to justify continued detention
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Decision subject to judicial review if findings lack evidentiary support or legal error
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Intermediate standard for mixed fact and law questions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient consideration of current dangerousness and alternatives
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: History of interactions with law enforcement, rehabilitation evidence
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued he was not a current risk and suitable for release
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and release on bail
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility and detention based on criminality
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Adequacy of consideration of evidence and alternatives
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Evidence considered but not sufficiently weighed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Detention maintained due to perceived danger
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review under Federal Court rules
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: History of gang association and related charges
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Danger to the public, criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Link between past conduct and potential future risk
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Board record, police reports, applicant testimony
Crimes.Outcome: Court found decision unreasonable, ordered new hearing
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Perceived ongoing danger and flight risk
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to adequately assess current risk and alternatives

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Insufficient analysis of current danger and alternatives
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Detention extended based on public safety concerns
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged drug trafficking and gang-related activity
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Prior involvement in organized crime and drug offenses
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Connection between past criminal behavior and potential reoffending
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Police records, Board proceedings, applicant statements
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to meaningfully consider rehabilitation and less restrictive options

Legal_Issue: Can the applicants' removal be stayed based on irreparable harm or serious issue?
Credibility_Assessment: The RPD found the applicants' story not credible
PRRA confirmed no risk of torture or harm
No new evidence was presented to overturn credibility findings
Basis_of_Claim: Claimed irreparable harm to delay removal
Legal_Standard: Stay of removal requires: a serious issue, irreparable harm if not granted, and greater harm on balance of convenience

Legal_Issue: Whether applicants can prove irreparable harm to justify a stay of removal
Evidence_Assessment: Business loss and potential U.S. detention were unsubstantiated; no evidence of life-threatening harm upon return
Decision_Outcome: Motion denied, removal order to proceed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to meet burden of proving irreparable harm
Credibility_Factor: Claims discredited; no credible risk found by Refugee Division and PRRA officer
Legal_Rule: Irreparable harm must be proven, not speculative, and cannot rely solely on discredited claims
Standard_of_Review: Assessment based on prior tribunal decisions and Federal Court review
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk in returning to Turkey, potential harm in the U.S.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Findings of Refugee Division and PRRA officer, lack of evidence on business loss and detention risk
Legal_Framework: Immigration and refugee protection legislation, stay of removal procedures
Authority: Federal Court, Refugee Division, PRRA officer

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Memon was a member of MQM-A from 1994 to 1999, an organization found to engage in terrorism based on credible evidence including reports from Amnesty International.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident or applicant for admission
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on MQM-A's activities including torture chambers and kidnappings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: The IAD found the evidence credible and compelling; court found assessment reasonable.
Crimes.Outcome: Mr. Memon remains inadmissible to Canada
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of IAD's inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: The IAD reasonably concluded that MQM-A engaged in terrorism against civilians and non-combatants, and Mr. Memon’s membership triggered inadmissibility under IRPA.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a member of an organization that there are reasonable grounds to believe engages, has engaged or will engage in acts of terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with a terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: MQM-A engaged in terrorism including torture and kidnapping
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in an organization involved in violent and terroristic acts
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: High – based on credible documentary sources including international human rights reports
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Distinction between MQM factions and whether membership implies support for terrorism
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: The court accepted the IAD's credibility assessment of the evidence linking MQM-A to terrorism.
Credibility_Factors: Consistency of reporting across time and sources
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of membership and organizational linkage to terrorism
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility to Canada and deportation order

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Refugee Protection Decision
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Application_Facts: The Board considered an internal flight alternative (IFA) without notifying counsel, who believed submissions were unnecessary as only delay was raised.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide opportunity to address material issue (IFA)
Evidence_Used: Board's decision record, applicant’s counsel submissions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of opportunity to present evidence on IFA
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee protection decision
Remedy_Sought: Remittal for reconsideration by a differently constituted Board
Standard_of_Review: Correctness or reasonableness, depending on issue
Decision_Rationale: The Board violated natural justice by deciding on IFA without affording counsel the chance to respond due to misleading communication.
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's credibility assessment of the applicants' refugee claim reasonable and based on substantial evidence?
Governing_Law: Standard of patent unreasonableness in judicial review of administrative decisions
Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions in applicant's testimony regarding location of kidnapping and delayed departure from Mexico
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision upheld; application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate patently unreasonable decision
Legal_Rule: Federal Court applies standard of patent unreasonableness to Board's factual findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged lack of credibility in refugee claim assessment
Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed; Board's decision found valid
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's testimony, timing of events, travel details
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Federal Court jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Overturning of Board's rejection of refugee claim
Legal_Provision: Section 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (judicial review)
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria
Application_Facts: Applicant fled Afghanistan due to Taliban threats; claimed extortion and night letters; wealthy businessman status considered
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with residency requirements for protection
Evidence_Used: Credibility findings from RPD, night letter, extortion claims, personal background as a businessman
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence of threat beyond workplace, insufficient proof of targeted persecution
Credibility_Assessment: RAD deferred to RPD's credibility findings, found applicant's claims not sufficiently credible
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed by RPD and RAD
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee, protection from removal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under Section 96 and danger under Section 97 of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: No credible risk of persecution or danger upon return; applicant’s wealth and lack of broader threats undermined claim

Application_Facts: Respondent was absent from Canada for 776 days over four years; maintained strong family, social, and financial ties to Canada; absences deemed temporary
Residency_Compliance: Partially non-compliant with physical presence but compliant under central mode of existence test
Evidence_Used: Family ties, social connections, financial ties in Canada, travel history
Credibility_Assessment: Respondent found credible; connections to Canada assessed as substantial
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application approved by citizenship judge
Relief_Sought: Minister sought cancellation of citizenship approval due to insufficient physical presence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo test for central mode of existence
Decision_Rationale: Judge reasonably concluded that respondent centralized mode of existence in Canada despite absences

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 171 days during the four-year period preceding the application, falling short of the required 1,095 days of physical residency
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate reasons provided by Citizenship Judge; failure to explain calculations or consider all evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not adequately address or analyze submitted evidence including ICES and OHIP records
Remedy_Sought: New hearing before a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical residence requirement of 1,095 days in four years
Decision_Rationale: Decision found unreasonable due to lack of justification, transparency, and intelligibility in the Judge's reasoning

Legal_Issue: Does Richardson International Ltd. have a valid maritime lien on the vessel 'Mys Chikhacheva' under U.S. law?
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies on Russian, Cypriot, and U.S. maritime laws
Decision_Outcome: Judgment granted to Richardson for $336,969.84 with pre-judgment interest and costs
Burden_of_Proof: Supplier of necessaries must establish valid provision of services and applicable maritime lien under governing law
Credibility_Factor: Authorization by bareboat charterer Starodubskoe; explicit choice of U.S. law in contracts
Legal_Rule: Under U.S. maritime law, a supplier of necessaries to a vessel is entitled to a maritime lien unless explicitly waived
Standard_of_Review: Application of U.S. maritime law based on contractual choice of law
Grounds_for_Claim: Provision of fuel, provisions, and technician services to the vessel 'Mys Chikhacheva' by Richardson International Ltd.
Outcome_on_Merits: Richardson has a valid maritime lien on the 'Mys Chikhacheva' for $336,969.84 under U.S. maritime law
Key_Evidence_Considered: Contracts between Richardson and Starodubskoe, ownership claims by Bering, role of Starodubskoe as bareboat charterer
Legal_Framework: U.S. maritime law, principles of maritime liens, contract law
Defendant_Response: Bering's claim of ownership and challenge to validity of lien
Remedy_Requested: Maritime lien enforcement for $336,969.84, pre-judgment interest, and costs
Outcome: Judgment in favor of Richardson International Ltd.
Legal_Provision: U.S. maritime lien statute for necessaries

Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 167 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether an oral hearing was required for credibility assessment
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Serious criminality under IRPA due to drug trafficking conviction
Risk_Nexus: Claimed risk upon removal to Jamaica due to sexual orientation
Basis_for_Decision: Insufficient evidence to support claim, not a credibility issue
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: None found – no oral hearing required

Crimes.Crime_Name: Conspiring to commit an indictable offence (forgery of a Canadian passport)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Deportation based on danger opinion under IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister's Delegate erred in finding no evidence of LTTE death threats

Crimes.Application_Error: Patent unreasonableness due to failure to address evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Risk of persecution or torture upon return
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by different panel

Crimes.Crime_Name: Conspiring to commit an assault causing bodily harm
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Multiple convictions including violent and fraud-related
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential for reoffending or ongoing threat
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Applicant targeted by LTTE due to defection or cooperation
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence presented but not assessed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Failure by delegate to evaluate credibility constitutes error
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – focus on deportation consequence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Deportation based on danger opinion under IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister's Delegate erred in dismissing evidence of LTTE threats
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to engage with documentary evidence of threats
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show risk of persecution/torture
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Affidavit and letter not assessed for reliability

Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA Part 1 – Inadmissibility and removal orders
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged deportation based on risk in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of deportation, reconsideration of danger opinion

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Involvement with LTTE, a listed terrorist entity
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat linked to terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: LTTE issued death threats against applicant
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Retaliation for perceived disloyalty or cooperation
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Attempt to interfere with legal process
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Alleged involvement leading to security concerns
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Affidavit and letter dismissed without scrutiny
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Blanket rejection of threat evidence without analysis
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No assessment conducted by delegate
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities for risk assessment
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Deportation if deemed not at risk of torture/persecution

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Amount exceeding $5000, pattern of criminal behavior
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History includes forgery, assault conspiracy, breach of trust
Crimes.Risk_Type: Public safety risk due to recidivism concern
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Economic crime with potential for reoffending
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Applicant targeted due to past affiliations
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence provided but not properly evaluated
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Failure to analyze sworn statements

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether use of forged passport and false identity constitutes serious non-political crime
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant used forged documents to flee persecution in Georgia
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Mitigating factors, likelihood of actual sentence, context of persecution
Crimes.Application_Error: Focused on maximum penalties without considering mitigating factors
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Presumption of seriousness based on 10+ year maximum penalty, rebuttable
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Lack of criminal history, context of flight from persecution
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Seriousness determined by sentencing range and mitigating circumstances
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of forged passport and false identity under duress
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration by different panel
Crimes.Authority: Supreme Court guidance on seriousness of crimes

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection due to serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether forgery of passport constitutes serious crime under IRPA and Refugee Convention
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant used forged passport to escape persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Likelihood of actual sentence, place in sentencing range
Crimes.Application_Error: Relied solely on maximum penalty without contextual analysis
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Presumption of seriousness for 10+ year max penalty, rebuttable
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Mitigating circumstances, purpose of forgery (to flee persecution)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Analysis must consider real risk of serious sentence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Crime committed to avoid persecution in Georgia

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection based on seriousness of identity fraud
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether identity fraud is serious enough to trigger exclusion
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of false identity to flee persecution in Georgia
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Hybrid nature of offense, possibility of summary conviction
Crimes.Application_Error: Failed to consider lesser sentencing options and context
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Maximum penalty presumption with rebuttal based on actual severity
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential for 6-month sentence under summary conviction
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Seriousness depends on position within sentencing spectrum
Crimes.Application_Factor: Identity fraud used as means to escape persecution
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration by differently constituted panel
Crimes.Authority: Supreme Court guidance on assessing crime seriousness

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection due to alleged serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether shoplifting and identity fraud amount to serious criminality under IRPA and Refugee Convention
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to assess mitigating factors related to persecution
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside, remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On party alleging exclusion due to serious criminality
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s explanation for using false identity linked to persecution
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Serious criminality requires max penalty ≥10 years, but rebuttable by context
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Use of forged passport and shoplifting while in U.S.
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature and context of identity fraud and shoplifting
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Acted to escape persecution in Georgia
Crimes.Authority: Supreme Court's nuanced test for seriousness of crimes

Legal_Issue: Were the Board's credibility and state protection findings reasonable?
Outcome: Decision unreasonable due to flawed credibility analysis and insufficient consideration of gender guidelines
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned applicant’s credibility based on implausible assumptions about domestic abuse, ignored context of gender-related persecution
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant claimed refugee status due to domestic abuse
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Flawed credibility analysis, inadequate consideration of gender guidelines
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review application filed in Federal Court
Application_Error: Presumed state protection without sufficient basis
Legal_Standard: Credibility and state protection assessments must be reasonable

Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant used a fraudulent Israeli passport to flee domestic abuse in Georgia
Evidence_Used: Details omitted in testimony, improvements in Georgia's handling of domestic abuse
Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to implausibility of abuse and omissions
Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable, case referred back
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable assessment of credibility and state protection
Decision_Rationale: Inadequate consideration of gender-related persecution guidelines

Aggravating_Factors: Lack of effective state protection, cultural barriers
Risk_Nature: Systemic failure to protect women from domestic violence
Targeted_Victimization: Women subjected to domestic abuse in Georgia
Evidence_Credibility: Undermined by Board based on implausible assumptions
Credibility_Assessment: Flawed due to lack of gender-sensitive analysis

Application_Facts: Applicant obtained documents through deception to escape domestic abuse
Evidence_Used: Nature of abuse, circumstances of flight
Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonably questioned based on implausible assumptions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness in credibility and protection assessments
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for credibility, correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Failure to apply gender-specific guidelines and proper credibility analysis

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Sidhu spent only 26 days in Canada over a five-year period
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: No, only 26 days in Canada over 5 years
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: IAD failed to properly assess evidence and ignored inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence for claims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in Sidhu's claims were not addressed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD allowed appeal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court set aside IAD decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: IAD decision was unreasonable due to failure to consider all evidence and relevant factors

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet residency obligations under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unreasonable grant of humanitarian and compassionate relief despite non-compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court set aside IAD decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Contradictory evidence about business and family situation not assessed
Evidence_Type: Claims of family obligations in India
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 28 and Section 67, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Minimal physical presence in Canada (26 days)
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Appeal before IAD, followed by judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictory evidence regarding claimant's activities and residence in India
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family ties and hardship claimed but inadequately supported
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD granted relief; Federal Court remitted for redetermination

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant's husband was subject to an enforceable removal order
Crimes.Evidence_Type: CBSA deferral documentation, removal order status
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s.113(1)(e) of Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inclusion of a family member subject to an enforceable removal order
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Deferral does not equate to a stay; removal order remained enforceable
Crimes.Application_Error: Applicant believed deferral constituted a stay
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Enforceability of removal orders under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Husband added to permanent residency application despite removal order
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of permanent residency application upheld

Crimes.Violation_Type: Ineligibility due to family member’s enforceable removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA and Regulations – Live-in Caregiver Class eligibility
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA and Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant’s husband subject to enforceable removal order; only deferral granted by CBSA
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking permanent residency under Live-in Caregiver Class
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to inclusion of inadmissible family member
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal order records, CBSA deferral notice
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question and overturning of refusal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Enforceable removal order renders applicant ineligible; deferral is not a stay

Violation_Type: Judicial review of PRRA decision post-removal
Application_Facts: Applicant is a Tamil from Sri Lanka who alleged risk of persecution; PRRA application was denied; applicant was removed from Canada despite seeking judicial review.
Procedural_Issue: Filing of judicial review after removal; mootness of application
Jurisdictional_Issue: Court may lack authority to order return or reassessment after removal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Mootness doctrine; discretion to hear in cases of legal uncertainty and adversarial context
Decision_Rationale: Application largely moot post-removal, but court exercised discretion to hear due to legal uncertainty and adversarial process

Dispute_Type: Regulatory compliance for issuing a Notice of Compliance (NOC) for additional drug indications
Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister is precluded by s. 7(1)(b) of the NOC Regulations from issuing an NOC to Apotex for new claims without a fresh NOA served on Merck
Governing_Law: Section 7(1)(b) and Section 5 of the NOC Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Apotex served a 1993 NOA regarding Lovastatin's manufacture and use; Merck challenged only the manufacturing process, not the new claims
Decision_Outcome: Court ruled in favor of Apotex
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to demonstrate compliance with s. 5 of the NOC Regulations
Legal_Rule: Under s. 7(1)(b), the Minister cannot issue an NOC until the second person complies with s. 5, which requires alleging non-infringement or accepting patent expiration
Grounds_for_Claim: Merck had prior opportunity to contest the patent issues but did not contest the new claims
Outcome_on_Merits: The Minister is not precluded from issuing the NOC as Apotex complied with s. 5 via the 1993 NOA
Key_Evidence_Considered: Service of the 1993 NOA, scope of Merck's challenge limited to manufacturing process
Defendant_Response: Merck did not contest the new claims in response to the 1993 NOA
Remedy_Requested: Issuance of NOC for new claims without requirement of a new NOA
Outcome: NOC allowed to be issued without a new NOA
Authority: Minister of Health, Court interpreting NOC Regulations

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Egypt; PRRA rejected due to lack of new evidence showing worsened country conditions; officer failed to consider 2004-2005 human rights reports indicating deterioration
Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident or Protected Person seeking refugee protection
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer failed to compare country condition changes between 2002 and 2004-2005; inadequate assessment of new evidence
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports from 2004-2005 documenting human rights abuses in Egypt
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of comparative analysis between prior conditions and new evidence on country conditions
Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged; focus was on objective country condition evidence
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision found patently unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Reassessment of PRRA based on updated country condition evidence
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different PRRA panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness standard in administrative law
Decision_Rationale: Officer's failure to consider credible evidence of deteriorating human rights conditions rendered the decision perverse and outside acceptable limits

Application_Facts: Zhang was absent from Canada for significant periods due to her husband's employment in Japan; citizenship judge considered passive connections and failed to assess relevant facts such as family ties outside Canada
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet three years of physical residence in Canada during the four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to properly apply the qualitative test for residence
Evidence_Used: Periods of absence from Canada, family ties abroad, nature of connections to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess factual basis for residency, including external family ties
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court allowed the appeal, set aside the citizenship judge's decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Setting aside of the grant of citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Qualitative test for residence under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not meet statutory residency requirement; improper consideration of passive connections instead of actual physical presence and relevant factual circumstances

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants' refugee claims were previously rejected; they submitted a PRRA alleging religious persecution in Ukraine
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimants seeking PRRA protection
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to pending removal order
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged risk not sufficiently substantiated with new evidence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer assessed new evidence and credibility without re-litigating prior decisions
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Country condition reports, applicant submissions, documentation from interested parties
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of personalized risk of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably weighed credibility and relevance of evidence, including from interested parties
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Reversal of PRRA decision and grant of protected person status
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order for reconsideration or declaration of invalidity
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No substantial risk of persecution established based on new evidence and country conditions
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(1) of IRPA – failure to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after refugee claims were denied and applied for PRRA
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to expired visa and refusal of status renewal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: None found; focus was on risk assessment, not fraud
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Evaluation of new evidence in PRRA context despite prior adverse findings
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's supervisory jurisdiction over PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: New documents, country condition updates, personal affidavits
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, specific, and current evidence demonstrating personal risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility concerns carried forward reasonably from prior decisions
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal and protected person status
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and remittal for re-assessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No objective basis to conclude applicants face a danger of persecution upon return

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility and authenticity of claimed persecution risk
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer reasonably evaluated new evidence and credibility
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA application rejected; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer assessed but did not arbitrarily dismiss evidence from interested parties
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, letters from religious groups, media reports
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 97–98 IRPA (PRRA eligibility and risk assessment)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged religious persecution as Pentecostals in Ukraine
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of individualized risk despite generalized societal prejudice
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: PRRA assessment followed by Federal Court judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: None identified; officer properly exercised discretion
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence outright ignored; some deemed insufficiently relevant or dated
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing, source reliability, and specificity of evidence
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No finding of forged documents; concerns related to probative value

Crimes.Crime_Name: Religious persecution claim denial under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Denial of protection based on religious persecution claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA Sections 96, 97(1), and international refugee law principles
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA application denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Religious persecution due to Pentecostal faith in Ukraine
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No subjective or objective basis for fear of persecution established
Crimes.Institutional_Action: PRRA assessment concluding no substantial risk
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Canada, under federal immigration and refugee protection regime
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Failed refugee claimant seeking protection via PRRA
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Christians, particularly non-Orthodox denominations in parts of Ukraine
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State able and willing to protect religious minorities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Generalized social discrimination, not state-sponsored or condoned violence
Crimes.Credibility: Partially accepted but insufficient to establish personal risk
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate legal and practical protections available
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Societal prejudice without evidence of systemic persecution
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Non-state actors and societal elements, not government authorities

Crime_Name: Unreasonable delay in processing immigration application
Legal_Provision_Violated: Duty to decide as soon as possible under the Immigration Act
Application_Facts: Applicant filed for permanent residence in 1996; significant delays occurred post-1998 due to CSIS inactivity despite completion of criminal sentence
Evidence_Used: Timeline of application, periods of inactivity, CSIS delays
Remedy_Sought: Order to issue decision by a specified date
Legal_Standard_Applied: Writ of mandamus requires clear duty and lack of alternative remedy
Decision_Rationale: Overall delay was unreasonable, especially due to post-conviction inactivity by CSIS

Prior_Criminality: Applicant had a prior criminal conviction
Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high, involving violent offense
Legal_Provision: Criminal Code - Assault with a weapon

Dispute_Type: Dispute over whether the elimination of a job position constituted a 'discontinuance of function' under the Canada Labour Code
Legal_Issue: Did the Adjudicator correctly determine that there was no discontinuance of function under Section 242(3.1)(a) of the Canada Labour Code?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application in Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: The Applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence to support their claim
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Adjudicator's decision upheld
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant had the burden to prove lack of economic justification and improper notification
Legal_Rule: Section 242(3.1)(a) bars complaints if dismissal is due to lack of work or discontinuance of a function, unless economic justification is proven
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unjust dismissal due to elimination of position without economic justification or proper notice
Outcome_on_Merits: Adjudicator's decision found reasonable; complaint not barred by jurisdictional provisions
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of economic justification, notification of termination
Legal_Framework: Canada Labour Code, Part III – Unjust Dismissal
Defendant_Response: Respondent claimed discontinuance of function; Adjudicator found no economic justification
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Adjudicator’s jurisdictional ruling
Outcome: Application dismissed; costs awarded against the Applicant
Legal_Provision: Section 242(3.1)(a) of the Canada Labour Code

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Death threats linked to land dispute
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Well-founded fear of persecution and risk to life
Crimes.Risk_Type: Personalized threat due to familial conflict
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inadequate by Officer

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Pattern of violence, murders of associates
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Dismissed without proper analysis

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: s. 97, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of death and lack of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, domestic immigration law

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: s. 113(a), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: New medical evidence of PTSD and depression
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Survivor of prolonged threats and violence

Crimes.Application_Facts: New evidence of threats and murders post-RPD
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lawfully present in Canada during PRRA
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to reasonably assess new evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Flawed assessment

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Fraudulent claim of land ownership leading to threats
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant credible; fraud attributed to cousin
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to fraudulent land seizure
Crimes.Application_Factor: Link between fraud and personal risk
